paragraphs: Addis Ababa University has been led by presidents who have taken the university on a path of great accomplishments and national and continental prominence, expanding its faculties, promoting research, and fostering international partnerships.  Since its founding as the University College of Addis Ababa in 1950, there have been 14 presidents, two of them expatriates, with different academic backgrounds and histories.

Lucien Matte SJ (1907–1973) was a Canadian Jesuit priest and educator. He was President of the University of Sudbury and and the founding president of Addis Ababa University. In 1946, Emperor Haile Selassie, who favoured the Jesuit educational philosophy, asked Matte to help organize the country's educational system. The emperor followed this in 1950 with a request that Matte help establish a university. This maiden postsecondary establishment was named the University College of Addis Ababa (now Addis Ababa University) and Matte served as President from 1952 to 1962. He then served as president of the University of Sudbury from 1962 to 1966

He was the first Ethiopian President of Haile Selassie I University. After serving in the Private Office of the Emperor, he skilfully led the University during the first critical decade of the University. He was skilful at negotiating and calming students during a period of increasing radicalization and protecting students and the University from intrusion by the government.

Dr. Aklilu Habte belonged to the first cohort of graduates of the University College of Addis Ababa. As the second Ethiopian president, he led the University at a time of fierce confrontation between radical students and the imperial government. Dr Aklilu also served as the first Ethiopian Dean of the Faculty of Education before his brief period of presidency.

Dr. Taye led AAU as President in the tumultuous times that followed the resignation of Dr. Aklilu and other key members of the administration in the aftermath of the Ethiopian Revolution. His presidency oversaw the Edget Behibret Zemecha (Development through co-operation enlightenment and work) which mobilized university students in national mass literacy programs and rural development.

Dr. Duri was President of AAU twice: (1976-1985) and (1993-1995). In both terms of office, he was appointed as a crisis leader to restore normalcy at the University following periods of instability. After he was brought in as “Caretaker administrator” by the Derg, he soon assumed full mantle as President. He was responsible “for the respectable survival of the university, with much of its integrity intact during the most difficult years.” In 1993, he was appointed as President following the crisis of January 1993 that led to the closure of the University for several months and dismissal of the top University leadership.

An academic administrator at HSIU during the imperial days and the early Derg period, Dr. Abiy Kifle became President when the University under Dr. Duri’s leadership was returning to normalcy. His period saw steady consolidation of the university but also witnessed student protests in later years. The presidency was also marred by the decision to send students and staff for national campaigns in Metekal and Gambella (1985) and conscription of students into the armed forces towards the end of the civil war in 1991.

Professor Alemayehu was the first President of the University to be elected by the university community. His tenure was cut short because of the crisis of January1993 which pitted students against government security forces. The President and his VP’s were dismissed from their positions for endorsing the call for a thorough investigation of the violence directed against students.

Dr. Duri was President of AAU twice: (1976-1985) and (1993-1995). In both terms of office, he was appointed as a crisis leader to restore normalcy at the University following periods of instability. After he was brought in as “Caretaker administrator” by the Derg, he soon assumed full mantle as President. He was responsible “for the respectable survival of the university, with much of its integrity intact during the most difficult years.” In 1993, he was appointed as President following the crisis of January 1993 that led to the closure of the University for several months and dismissal of the top University leadership.

Professor Mogesie Ashenafi led AAU as president from Dec. 1995- Sep 2000. Before assuming the presidency, Professor Mogessie served Awassa College of Agricultural which was then under AAU for years from graduate assistant to associate professor, besides holding positions of academic leadership as head of department and assistant dean. An exceptionally prolific researcher with an impressive track record of scientific publications in leading journals in his area of microbiology, he was promoted to full professor in November 1998. As President, Professor Mogessie was instrumental in the signing of a number of cooperation agreements between AAU and foreign universities.

Professor Eshetu was the second President of the University who was elected through the active participation of the University community. His tenure opened auspiciously with the holding of a three-week long conference between the University community and the Prime Minister in the summer of 2002 that envisaged a new period of University-Government relations. However, this honeymoon ended shortly with Prof. Eshetu and his VP’s resigning in December 2002 protesting the imposition of a new staff assessment system over the University by the Ministry of Education.

Prof. Andreas was a highlycontroversial figure who run the University for nearly a decade. His period saw a major expansion of different programs in the University as well as attempts to implementBPR (Business Process Reengineering) as a tool in reforming university administration.

An agricultural scholar, Professor Admasu obtained a BSc degree from Alemaya College of Agriculture, and an MSc and a PhD in Crop Ecology and Resource Conservation from Wageningen University in the Netherlands. Professor Admasu Tsegaye became President of Addis Ababa University in March 2011. Before his ascent to the presidency, he held numerous administrative positions including Academic Programs Officer, Vice President for Administration and Development, Vice President for Academic Affairs and Research, and President of Hawassa University. He also served as chairperson of several bodies).

Professor Tassew Woldehanna served as AAU president from 2018-2023. He was previously AAU Vice President for Research and Technology Transfer, and Dean of the College of Business and Economics where he holds a position as Professor of Economics. A veteran economist, Professor Tassew holds an MSc in Agricultural and Environmental Economics and Policy and a PhD in Economics from Wageningen University, Netherlands, where he has been a visiting Professor in Household and Agricultural Economics since 2000.

paragraphs: GAT Exam Schedule (Monday January 05, 2026 Morning and Afternoon Session)

Please find attached the exam venue schedules for the GAT, which will be administered on Monday, January 5, 2026, in both morning and afternoon sessions. The schedules cover applicants who registered during the period December 09–30, 2025. The schedule for applicants who registered on December 31, 2025 will be announced separately; their exam will also be conducted on the same date (afternoon session).

All visually impaired candidates are required to take the GAT at the Disability Center, Lab 1 (Main Campus). If your name is mistakenly listed under a different exam room, please report directly to the Disability Center, Lab 1, on the exam day.

paragraphs: Addis Ababa University (AAU) is a pioneer university in Ethiopia, located in Ababa, the capital city of Ethiopia. It is the most prestigious national university and one of the best in Africa. It commenced as the University College of Addis Ababa in 1950 initially consisting of the Faculties of Arts and Science, eventually becoming a fully-fledged college when it earned a chartered status in 1954.

In February 1961, various colleges, including the Theological College, formed Haile Selassie I University. The emperor offered his "Guenete Leul Palace" (ገነተ ልዑል ቤተመንግስት), which was at the heart of the Sidist Kilo main campus, to serve as the nucleus of administration. Following the 1974 Ethiopian Revolution, the university was briefly renamed the University of Ethiopia (National University) before it assumed its present name - Addis Ababa University in 1975.

In the aftermath of the revolution, Addis Ababa University was closed for two years, and students and staff were mobilised for service in what was known as the Development through Cooperation Campaign: "Ideget Behibret zemecha" (እድገት በህብረት ዘመቻ), designed to bring enlightenment to the rural population in the spirit of the revolution.

The university opened its first Master's programs in 1979 and its first PhD programs in 1987 that saw massive expansion across all academic fields in subsequent years. . In both national and African yearly rankings, AAU continues to secure a position of prestige.

The Council of Ministers of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia (FDRE), approved an autonomous establishment draft regulation of Addis Ababa University (AAU) during its 23rd regular meeting on 4 August, 2023. The Federal Government issued the University Autonomy Proclamation to ensure higher education institutions' academic independence and freedom from political and administrative interference. Accordingly, a draft regulation was prepared and submitted to the Council of Ministers to transform AAU into a self governing institution. and to implement the autonomous university system as a role model for other Federal Universities in the country. Since September 2023, with the participation of its colleges and research institutions, Addis Ababa University has been carrying out multifaceted technical and professional tasks in connection with the reform process. The university management has been diligently involved in addressing pitfalls and drawbacks. As a result of effective university communications and partnerships with relevant global and national institutions, Addis Ababa University is now on the correct path to full autonomy. It is expected that autonomy will bring numerous benefits to the nation's oldest and best university in terms of added visibility and prestige arising from improved performance across all segments of the university’s mission.
Future Direction: Consolidating Leadership in Science and Scholarship

The University has prepared a five year Strategic Plan for 2024 -2028 to maintain its prestigious position and hasten its progress to full autonomy. The Vision, Mission, and Values in this five-year strategic plan are concise statements that guide its diverse bodies with a sense of purpose,  and help them execute the expected tasks to meet stated goals and objectives. The strategic plan was enriched with input from stakeholders and went through a long process involving careful research and assessment of past and current initiatives. The Plan encompasses the agenda which the university will implement during the five-year roadmap to enable it to contribute to the country’s social, economic, political and cultural transformation.

The Strategic Plan addresses nine strategic themes and initiatives with the prime intention of ripening effective and accountable governance and organizational culture with a solid structure and system. Out of all this, an extraordinary educational experience will arise that enables students to master higher learning and achieve better, enhancing their employability and entrepreneurial competence. By carefully integrating the trilogy of teaching, research and community services, Addis Ababa University will combat Ethiopia’s multiple socio-economic, political and environmental challenges.

Following the 1974 Ethiopian Revolution, the university was briefly renamed the University of Ethiopia (National University) before it assumed its present name - Addis Ababa University in 1975. In the aftermath of the revolution, Addis Ababa University was closed for two years, and students and staff were mobilised for service in what was known as the Development through Cooperation Campaign: "Ideget Behibret zemecha" (እድገት በህብረት ዘመቻ), designed to bring enlightenment to the rural population in the spirit of the revolution. The university opened its first Master's programs in 1979 and its first PhD programs in 1987 that saw massive expansion across all academic fields in subsequent years. . In both national and African yearly rankings, AAU continues to secure a position of prestige.The Present StatusThe Council of Ministers of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia (FDRE), approved an autonomous establishment draft regulation of Addis Ababa University (AAU) during its 23rd regular meeting on 4 August, 2023. The Federal Government issued the University Autonomy Proclamation to ensure higher education institutions' academic independence and freedom from political and administrative interference. Accordingly, a draft regulation was prepared and submitted to the Council of Ministers to transform AAU into a self governing institution. and to implement the autonomous university system as a role model for other Federal Universities in the country. Since September 2023, with the participation of its colleges and research institutions, Addis Ababa University has been carrying out multifaceted technical and professional tasks in connection with the reform process. The university management has been diligently involved in addressing pitfalls and drawbacks. As a result of effective university communications and partnerships with relevant global and national institutions, Addis Ababa University is now on the correct path to full autonomy. It is expected that autonomy will bring numerous benefits to the nation's oldest and best university in terms of added visibility and prestige arising from improved performance across all segments of the university’s mission. Future Direction: Consolidating Leadership in Science and ScholarshipThe University has prepared a five year Strategic Plan for 2024 -2028 to maintain its prestigious position and hasten its progress to full autonomy. The Vision, Mission, and Values in this five-year strategic plan are concise statements that guide its diverse bodies with a sense of purpose, and help them execute the expected tasks to meet stated goals and objectives. The strategic plan was enriched with input from stakeholders and went through a long process involving careful research and assessment of past and current initiatives. The Plan encompasses the agenda which the university will implement during the five-year roadmap to enable it to contribute to the country’s social, economic, political and cultural transformation.The Strategic Plan addresses nine strategic themes and initiatives with the prime intention of ripening effective and accountable governance and organizational culture with a solid structure and system. Out of all this, an extraordinary educational experience will arise that enables students to master higher learning and achieve better, enhancing their employability and entrepreneurial competence. By carefully integrating the trilogy of teaching, research and community services, Addis Ababa University will combat Ethiopia’s multiple socio-economic, political and environmental challenges.AnnouncementsFirst-Year Students Final online exam ScheduleJan 25, 2026AAU Connect Volume 10 – 75 Years of ExcellenceJan 22, 2026final examination schedule for the course Inclusiveness (for 2nd year Students)Jan 12, 2026GAT Exam Schedule (Monday January 05, 2026 Morning and Afternoon Session)Dec 31, 2025Submission of Updated Grade 12 Examination ResultsDec 25, 2025View allSubscribe to our Newsletter.Subscribe

paragraphs: Dr. Samuel Kifle (PhD) is President of Addis Ababa University (AAU), Ethiopia’s first autonomous public university and a national leader in higher education, research, and innovation. Appointed in August 2023, he has been entrusted with guiding AAU through a period of strategic transformation, advancing its mission to deliver world-class education, foster impactful research, and contribute to Ethiopia’s social and economic development.

With more than 20 years of progressive leadership experience in academia, public service, and institutional reform, Dr. Samuel has built a distinguished career at the intersection of education policy, management, and international collaboration. As State Minister for Higher Education (2021–2023), he spearheaded comprehensive reforms in curriculum modernization, governance structures, and quality assurance systems all initiatives that have reshaped Ethiopia’s higher education landscape. In his earlier role as State Minister for Science and Higher Education (2016–2021), he was instrumental in revising the national education roadmap during a period of political and institutional change, introducing forward-looking policies in pedagogy, organizational design, and institutional accountability.

Before these ministerial positions, Dr. Samuel played a central role in expanding access to higher education as General Manager of the Ministry of Education’s Higher Education Expansion Program (2015–2016), overseeing the creation of new institutions and programs nationwide. As General Director for Higher Education Administration Affairs (2013–2016), he implemented administrative reforms that improved efficiency, transparency, and service delivery across Ethiopian universities.

Dr. Samuel’s academic career began at Addis Ababa University, where he served as Lecturer in the College of Business and Economics (2002–2007), followed by his appointment as Assistant Professor at Jimma University (2010–2012). His teaching and research in accounting and finance, coupled with his contributions to curriculum development, reflect his enduring commitment to academic quality. He has also served as an external examiner for Addis Ababa University’s College of Business and Economics, ensuring academic standards in graduate research.

He earned his PhD in Commerce and Management Studies from Andhra University, India, in 2010, where he was awarded the Best PhD Thesis Medal Award. He also holds an MSc in Accounting and Finance (2006) and a BA in Accounting (2001), both from Addis Ababa University. His academic and professional journey has been enriched by international engagements, including collaborations with Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, the University of Hull, and the Fulbright Program, as well as a term as Visiting Professor at the International University College of Leuven, Belgium (2012–2013).

Beyond academia, Dr. Samuel has served on the management boards of several Public Universities, Government agencies and Financial Institutions.  He has also served as  an alternative member of the Steering Committee for the Partnership for Applied Science and Technology (PASET) in Africa.

Widely recognized for his integrity, reliability, and strategic vision, Dr. Samuel is a transformational leader who has successfully guided institutions through periods of change, crisis management, and policy innovation. His career reflects a consistent dedication to using education as a catalyst for national progress, ensuring that Ethiopian higher education remains globally competitive while deeply connected to the country’s development priorities.

paragraphs: Administration & Student Services Vice President

Abdurezak Mohammed Kuhil is an associate professor at the School of Commerce, College of Business & Economics, Addis Ababa University. He is currently the vice president for administration and student services at AAU and is a senior full-time academic staff member and researcher. He was the Chief Planning Officer of AAU prior to his current role. At the College of Business & Economics, he held academic leadership positions as associate dean for undergraduate programs and coordinator of the graduate programs office. He holds a doctorate degree in business leadership, an MBA, and a bachelor's degree in business education.

In graduate and undergraduate programs, Abdurezak has instructed students in a range of subjects, including organizational development, team management, leadership, and change management. He has also provided management and leadership training to numerous businesses and served as an organization and management consultant to numerous corporate enterprises.
Email:  vpass@aau.edu.et
Phone number +251111239783

paragraphs: Head of the President’s Office, in the rank of Vice President

Prof. Matiwos Ensermu Jaleta is Professor of Logistics and Supply Chain Management (LSCM) and currently serves as Head of the President’s Office, in the rank of Vice President, at Addis Ababa University (AAU). He holds a BA in Management, an MBA from Addis Ababa University, and a PhD in Commerce and Management Studies from Andhra University, India.

With over two decades of academic, research, and consultancy experience, Dr. Matiwos has led national logistics initiatives, including the establishment of the Ethiopian National Logistics Council and the Ethiopian National Logistics Strategy. His work spans capacity building, policy formulation, and strategic project leadership in logistics and supply chain management.

He is the author of Managing Logistics and Supply Chain in Ethiopia (first and revised second editions) and has published numerous peer-reviewed journal articles on logistics, supply chain management, sustainability, and organizational leadership. Internationally, Dr. Matiwos has engaged in professional training and collaborations, contributing significantly to the advancement of Ethiopia’s logistics sector through research, education, and advisory services.

paragraphs: Digitalization and Infrastructure Vice President

Dr. Wondwossen Mulugeta is an Assistant Professor at the School of Information Science (SIS), Addis Ababa University with a PhD degree in Information Technology engaged in teaching and research activities. He is currently serving as Vice President for Digitalization and Infrastructure at AAU. He has served the University as Director of Academic Staff Affairs, Associate Dean of College of Natural and Computational Sciences, Assistant Dean for the Faculty of Informatics over the past 20 years. He has also played many roles as chairman, member and technical expert of many ad-hoc committees in the university, public institutions and non-government organizations. Wondwossen specializes in machine learning, data science and natural language processing research area with long years of experience in database management and systems development practices.

Wondwossen has numerous project management and leadership experience in ICT related projects and services. He has also served in many organizations as Board of Director contributing in different strategic and long-term development initiatives with exceptional communication and leadership skills. Wondwossen had the chance to successfully complete numerous projects as an independent consultant as well as being a project manager and core team member. The projects span from requirement analysis and design to national surveys and information system development activities. His expertise and engagement in electronic based learning (eLearning) in higher education spans over 15 years impacting different technological interventions and initiatives. He was highly engaged in policy, strategy and system development for educational institution leadership, blended and full online learning systems in Ethiopia and beyond.
Email: wondwossen.mulugeta@aau.edu.et
Office: Main Campus, Administration Building 5th Floor.

paragraphs: Academic Vice President

The Office of the Academic Vice President is accountable to the President with responsibilities for leading, coordinating and facilitating the University’s academic affairs and the following major roles:
• Lead, coordinate and oversee responsibilities for development and management of graduate and undergraduate academic programs,
• Provide leadership in establishing academic priorities, plans for program development, faculty recruitment and development, and in managing the academic enterprise;

• Closely work with the President to assist in and provide support on academic affairs, and with other Vice Presidents to set the University’s broad academic directions/vision, priorities and policies;
• Develop and oversee the implementation of plans, policies, rules and guidelines governing academic programs, academic and technical staff, and students;

• Facilitate the accomplishment of the University’s mission and its academic goals through the establishment of programs, policies, procedures, and standards; in selection, evaluation, and development of faculty and staff; in review of academic programs; in allocation of funds; and in provision of information;
• Ensure the employment and promotion of academic staff is consistent with the University’s rules and procedures;
• Coordinate and set context for the University’s various colleges, programs, and services to maintain broad and coherent institutional perspective;
• Develop and implement the institutional-level planning initiatives that are essential to the strategic positioning of the University;
• Coordinate periodic academic program reviews and work with academic units in the review, study, and development of curriculum and in the improvement of instruction;
• Establish and facilitate collaboration with industries and other institutions in pursuit of the University’s mission;
• Support and ensure the programs of study; prepare and supply qualified graduates in knowledge, skills, and attitudes on the basis of the existing needs of the country;

• Ensure the University’s strategic and operational plans are in place for colleges and reporting units, monitoring and supporting best practices, monitoring performances, and promoting positive relations internally and externally.
Main campus/6Kilo, New administration building, second floor
Email: avp@aau.edu.et; jeilu.oumer@aau.edu.et

paragraphs: Partnership and Communication Vice President

Dr. Rahel A. Kebede, is an enthusiastic advocate for the well-being of children on our continent. As a pediatric pulmonary and critical care subspecialist, she is committed to amplifying their voices across the region, continent, and the world, advocating for improved access to high-quality healthcare. Having served as the immediate past clinical service director at Addis Ababa University’s teaching hospital, Tikur Anbessa Specialized Hospital, and currently holding the position of Partnership and Communication Vice President  for at Addis Ababa University, she is dedicated to enhancing education , research and healthcare quality through innovative and participatory leadership.

paragraphs: Empowering AAU’s Digital Future

The ICT and Digitalization Services enables digitally empowered academic ecosystem for Addis Ababa University. We provide secure, reliable, and modern ICT infrastructures and digital services that support learning, research, clinical services, informed decision making and administration.
Core Service Highlights
Data Center, Core IT and Cloud Infrastructures
Enterprise LAN, WLAN and WAN Infrastructures
Official Website and Online Gateway
Open Access Facilities
Smart Classroom and Campus
Digital Learning Platforms and Collaboration Tools
Enterprise Digital Platforms Services
Systems and Applications
Digital Communications
Security and Digital Risks Management
ICT and Digitalization Directorate
Addis Ababa University
Main /Sidist Kilo Campus
Email: ict@aau.edu.et
Website: www.aau.edu.et
lists: State-of-the-art Data centers to ensure reliable, secure, and scalable digital services
Cloud compute and storage infrastructure
Faculty compute and storage infrastructure
Wireless and wired connectivity services across  university premises and spaces
A centralized web portal offering streamlined access to academic, research, and administrative resources.
Features include updated news, announcements, events, and insights on ICT initiatives and services.
Over 95 computer centers, equipped with more than 2,000 internet connected computers support, support online tests, digital capacities and online sessions.
Launched one fully equipped smart classroom and 52 enhanced smart classrooms availed to promote interactive, green, and digital learning practices.

Hosts and maintains Learning Management Systems (LMS) such as Moodle and Or OpenedX enabling course delivery, assignment management, and collaborative learning environments for both faculty and students.
Fully functional state-of-the-art multimedia studio enabling the production of high-quality digital learning content.
Google Workspace for Education tools including Gmail, Google Classroom, Docs, and Drive in use supporting teaching, learning, and collaboration.
Provides secure access to university systems such as student records, registration portals, email, calendaring, and administrative workflows.
Ensures single sign-on solutions for a streamlined user experience.
Designs, develops, deploy and maintains systems, applications and dynamic websites tailored for academic departments, research centers, clinical services and administrative units.
Manages emails to enhance engagement and seamless commutations with internal and external stakeholders.
Implements robust Cybersecurity measures such as SSL encryption, firewalls, enterprise antivirus solution, and security audits to safeguard the university’s digital platforms.
Ensures fast, reliable, and high-availability web services through monitored performance, maintenance routines, and scalability.
Maintains a dedicated support chatbot, offering documents, FAQs, to assist users across the digital spectrum.
Enables timely support and maintenance services for infrastructure, systems, office equipment and devices

paragraphs: Academic calendar shall mean a list of academic activities arranged in a chronological order for one academic year.

Without prejudice to the School of Medicine and other academic units using a system of annual rather than semester course offerings, modular course offerings, as well as continuing and distance education programs, a normal semester at the University shall be 16 weeks of classes plus one week break before exams, and a summer/kiremt semester of 8-12 weeks.
At the University, a regular academic year commences on September and ends on June.
Summer semesters shall begin on July 01 and end on September 7.
In summer semesters, students shall only be carrying … _ of the normal semester load.
The duration of modular course offerings shall depend upon the ECTS/credit assigned to every modular course.
The duration of semesters for special in-service programs shall be determined according to the needs of every such program.
The Calendar for each year shall be prepared by the University Registrar in consultation with the AVP and approved by the Senate.
The Calendar, among other things, shall provide for the following:
·        the meetings of the Senate which will normally be once each semester;
·        the dates for the approval by the Senate of graduation ceremonies;
·        a minimum of four weeks inter-semester break.
·        inter-collegiate sports which shall take place during the inter-semester break;

·        dates of special programs, such as the in-service teachers’ education; and important dates of University academic work, such as registration, readmission, add and drop, examination periods, and postgraduate entrance examinations and annual reviews;

full_text: AAU | Addis Ababa University Academic CasesmenuNavigationAcademic CalendarAcademic CalendarAcademic calendar shall mean a list of academic activities arranged in a chronological order for one academic year.Without prejudice to the School of Medicine and other academic units using a system of annual rather than semester course offerings, modular course offerings, as well as continuing and distance education programs, a normal semester at the University shall be 16 weeks of classes plus one week break before exams, and a summer/kiremt semester of 8-12 weeks.At the University, a regular academic year commences on September and ends on June.Summer semesters shall begin on July 01 and end on September 7.In summer semesters, students shall only be carrying … _ of the normal semester load.The duration of modular course offerings shall depend upon the ECTS/credit assigned to every modular course.The duration of semesters for special in-service programs shall be determined according to the needs of every such program.The Calendar for each year shall be prepared by the University Registrar in consultation with the AVP and approved by the Senate.The Calendar, among other things, shall provide for the following:·        the meetings of the Senate which will normally be once each semester;·        the dates for the approval by the Senate of graduation ceremonies;·        a minimum of four weeks inter-semester break.·        inter-collegiate sports which shall take place during the inter-semester break;·        dates of special programs, such as the in-service teachers’ education; and important dates of University academic work, such as registration, readmission, add and drop, examination periods, and postgraduate entrance examinations and annual reviews; AnnouncementsFirst-Year Students Final online exam ScheduleJan 25, 2026AAU Connect Volume 10 – 75 Years of ExcellenceJan 22, 2026final examination schedule for the course Inclusiveness (for 2nd year Students)Jan 12, 2026GAT Exam Schedule (Monday January 05, 2026 Morning and Afternoon Session)Dec 31, 2025Submission of Updated Grade 12 Examination ResultsDec 25, 2025View allSubscribe to our Newsletter.Subscribe

paragraphs: AAU is dedicated to the provision of recreational and competitive sports for students, staff and faculty. A broad range of sporting events basketball, handball, tennis, athletics, table tennis, chess involve mass participation through the fan activities. Sports include inter-years, and inter-faculty sports competitions.

Each campus encourages indoor and outdoor activities and clubs help to offer more opportunities to students who are especially passionate about sports. The university also engages students in other extracurricular activities suitable to their desires and preferences including creative arts, volunteering and other areas of passion. Many clubs are formed based on taste and values and help to make university life fun. They also offer opportunities to learn and grow as well as showcase student talent.

paragraphs: The Ethnographic Museum of the Institute of Ethiopian Studies which is located at the main campus of Addis Ababa University (AAU) is the first university museum in Ethiopia. Since 1963 it has been serving the public at large in awareness creation of the about Ethiopia's diverge population of cultural resources. It is cultural institution dedicated to the preservation, reserve and presentation of Ethiopia's rich cultural heritage. The museum was established with the intention of conserving the nation's heritage, conducting pertinent research, and supporting educational endeavors of the People of Ethiopia Its collection exceeds 16,000 items, including religious and secular manuscripts, ceremonial items, icons, paintings, basketry, poetry, hand crafts, traditional weapons and musical instruments textiles, as well as, crosses, and philatelies. Some artifacts even date back to the early Aksumite period. The Ethnographic Museum is also a place where visitors enjoy as well as researchers conduct their research actively in projects related to heritage and museum studies. It is open to visitors from Monday to Sunday, excluding public holidays. Guides are available at all Times to provide information and insights about the collections. Entrance fees are charged at different rates for adults and students.

paragraphs: The College of Health Sciences (CHS) is a professional health sciences college, established in 2009/10 by the reorganization of previously separate institutions of health under one umbrella. The CHS is comprised of four schools and one teaching hospital. The four schools are the School of Medicine (SoM), the School of Pharmacy (SoP), the School of Public Health (SPH) and the School of Allied Health Sciences (SAHS). The SAHS offers professional training in nursing, midwifery and medical laboratory technology. The rationale behind the establishment of the CHS is to encourage cross-breeding across various disciplinary paradigms;

standardize curricula across disciplines; set standards and quality checks for the teaching-learning process; maximize human resources utilization through joint planning in teaching common courses and in conducting research; create opportunities in collaborative research and publication; maximize shared use of facilities for effectiveness and efficiency in teaching-learning, research and services, and create opportunities to address the health needs of the community in an integrated manner as a health team. All Schools of the CHS offer professional degrees at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels except for the School of Public Health which offers only postgraduate degrees at MSc and PhD levels.

However, the SPH is heavily engaged in offering public health courses to undergraduate students of the other Schools in the CHS. The CHS currently has over 5000 students, and employs over 600 full-time faculty members, The College currently offers eight undergraduate and over 70 postgraduate programs. The Tikur Abessa Specialized Hospital (TASH) is the teaching hospital of the College. TASH is the largest specialized hospital in Ethiopia, with over 700 beds, and serves as a training center for undergraduate and postgraduate medical students, dentists, nurses, midwives, pharmacists, medical laboratory technologists, radiology technologists, and others who shoulder the health problems of the community and the country at large.

In line with the mission and vision of AAU, the CHS exercises unique roles in training highly skilled health professionals at MSc, PhD, specialty and subspecialty levels. This allows it to contribute to the expansion of quality health care, education and research in the country. The CHS is the only institution where some specialized tertiary health care is rendered.
Moreover, under the new structure of AAU, the CHS is expected to enjoy a high level of academic and administrative autonomy.

paragraphs: The Addis Ababa University Startups Center is a dynamic hub for innovation and entrepreneurship, dedicated to empowering students, researchers, and early-stage entrepreneurs as they develop transformative ideas into scalable businesses. In addition to its main facilities, the center includes specialized innovation branches across other AAU campuses, such as the AAiT Innovation Center, the Science Innovation Center, and the Black Lion Hospital Health Innovation Center. These centers provide tailored resources, mentorship, and networking, opportunities to support development across diverse fields-from: technology and engineering to health sciences- driving Ethiopia's economic growth and addressing real world challenges through sustainable Innovation.

paragraphs: Community Radio-the Voice of AAU

AAU has been Ethiopia's best university and one of Africa's most respected institutions of higher learning. The University's community radio has been a part of the university's success as a prestigious public higher education.

While chiefly pandering to the university community, the radio station carries a variety of programming, including a news bulletin, sports, and music for the broader AA city community. It is also devoted to educational enrichment, community conversation, community engagement, and cultural development. The station promotes peaceful co-existence and intercultural tolerance through diverse formats including drama series, and inculcates a sense of good citizenship in the student community The radio station is located on the FBE campus and broadcasts daily for seven and a half hours.

paragraphs: The Ashenafi Kebede Performing Arts Center (AKPAC) is a newly established cultural and performance venue founded by Addis Ababa University, one of Africa’s oldest and most influential academic institutions. Located within the historic Yared School of Music, AKPAC stands as a renewed commitment to nurturing the arts, preserving cultural heritage, and expanding creative expression in Ethiopia.

The center is named in honor of Dr. Ashenafi Kebede a pioneering Ethiopian composer, conductor, and ethnomusicologist whose scholarship and artistry helped illuminate and safeguard Ethiopia’s musical traditions. His legacy guides our dedication to artistic integrity, cultural continuity, and educational excellence.

AKPAC serves as a creative home for musicians, actors, dancers, filmmakers, scholars, and cultural professionals. It hosts a wide range of programming, including concerts, theatre productions, film screenings, workshops, exhibitions, festivals, and community gatherings. It is a place where talent is cultivated, dialogue is encouraged, and culture is celebrated in all its diversity.

To advance and promote the performing arts in Ethiopia by providing a professional, inclusive, and inspiring environment for artistic creation, cultural education, and meaningful audience experiences.
To become a leading performing arts hub in Ethiopia and across Africa a center that sparks creativity, nurtures artistic growth, and strengthens the bond between culture, education, and community.
Host Your Event at AKPAC

Whether you are planning a concert, cultural celebration, theatrical performance, film screening, workshop, academic talk, or official gathering AKPAC offers a professional, well-equipped, and welcoming venue for your event.
Our facilities include:
· A 621-seat performance hall
· Fully equipped stage and lighting
· High-quality sound system and grand piano
· Spacious lobby and reception area
· Stand-by generator for uninterrupted events
· Secure parking and on-site security
· Convenient central location in Addis Ababa
Our team is dedicated to delivering smooth coordination and a memorable experience for performers, presenters, and guests.
